title: How do you teach empathy? - Jonathan Juravich

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique way that the author learned about empathy through their relationship with their grandmother?

options.label: A
options.text: They would watch Disney movies together and discuss the stories.

options.label: B
options.text: They would play board games together and talk about strategies.

options.label: C
options.text: They would go on walks together and discuss nature.

options.label: D
options.text: They would cook meals together and talk about recipes.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the author cautious when using the phrase "Walk in someone else's shoes" to explain empathy to their students?

options.label: A
options.text: They worry that it might confuse their students.

options.label: B
options.text: They worry that it might be too complicated for their students.

options.label: C
options.text: They worry that it might not be a practical way to understand empathy.

options.label: D
options.text: They worry that it might not be a good way to explain empathy to their students.

multiple-choice.question: What is the root of empathy, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: It is understanding and sharing the feelings of others.

options.label: B
options.text: It is being kind and helpful to others.

options.label: C
options.text: It is being aware of oneself and others.

options.label: D
options.text: It is being able to read minds.

multiple-choice.question: How does the author encourage their 5-year-old daughter to practice empathy?

options.label: A
options.text: They ask her to describe her day and talk about her feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: They ask her to help others in need.

options.label: C
options.text: They ask her to read books about empathy.

options.label: D
options.text: They ask her to watch videos about empathy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the polka dot house structure created by the author's students?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the unity of the class.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the trauma experienced by the students.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the community of the students.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the art supplies donated to the school.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's goal in encouraging their students to practice empathy?

options.label: A
options.text: To make them more aware of themselves and others.

options.label: B
options.text: To make them more kind and helpful to others.

options.label: C
options.text: To make them more understanding and sharing of the feelings of others.

options.label: D
options.text: To make them more confident and independent.

multiple-choice.question: How does the author's experience with their grandmother influence their approach to teaching empathy?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more patient and understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them more confident and assertive.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes them more aware of the importance of relationships and empathy.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes them more focused on academic achievement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the moment when the author's 5-year-old daughter covers her eyes in fear, mirroring Princess Jasmine on the screen?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that the daughter is empathizing with the princess.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that the daughter is not paying attention to the movie.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the daughter is not understanding the story.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that the daughter is not feeling any emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's message to their students and parents at the end of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more aware of themselves and others.

options.label: B
options.text: To be more kind and helpful to others.

options.label: C
options.text: To be more understanding and sharing of the feelings of others.

options.label: D
options.text: To be more confident and independent.

multiple-choice.question: How does the author's approach to teaching empathy differ from traditional methods?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more focused on academic achievement.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more focused on relationships and empathy.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more focused on discipline and punishment.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more focused on extracurricular activities.

title: Why can't dogs eat chocolate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because dogs are larger than humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Because dogs process theobromine more slowly than humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Because dogs have a different digestive system than humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Because dogs have a different metabolism than humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason humans can eat chocolate without getting sick?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans have a stronger immune system than dogs.

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans have a different diet than dogs.

options.label: D
options.text: Because humans have a different body temperature than dogs.

options.label: A

options.text: Because humans and dogs have the same digestive system.

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans and dogs have different diets.

options.text: Because humans and dogs have different ancestors.
